resources.string: Click to know the latest updates on Malaysia\'s vaccination program
Click to know the latest health updates from The Ministry of Health (MOH)

Company: US, Germany
Type of Vaccine:mRNA
Number of Shots: 2 shots, 21 days apart into muscle 
Effectiveness: 95%
Does NOT contain: Eggs, preservatives, latex

 What is the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine?
The Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine is an unapproved vaccine that may preventCOVID-19. There is no FDA-approved vaccine to prevent COVID-19.The FDA has authorized the emergency use of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine to prevent COVID-19 in individuals 12 years of age and older under an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).

Who should get the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine? 
FDA has authorized the emergency use of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine individuals 12 years of age and older.

Who should NOT get the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine 
You should not get the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine if you:
 • had a severe allergic reaction after a previous dose of this vaccine
 • had a severe allergic reaction to any ingredient of this vaccine

Company: China
Type of Vaccine: Inactivated virus vaccine
Number of Shots: 2 shots, 21 days apart into muscle 
Effectiveness: 68%
Does NOT contain: Eggs, preservatives, latex

 What is the Sinovac CoronaVac COVID-19 Vaccine?
The Sinovac CoronaVac COVID-19 Vaccine is an unapproved vaccine that may preventCOVID-19. There is no FDA-approved vaccine to prevent COVID-19.The FDA has authorized the emergency use of the Sinovac CoronaVac COVID-19 Vaccine to prevent COVID-19 in individuals 12 years of age and older under an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).

Who should get the Sinovac CoronaVac COVID-19 Vaccine? 
FDA has authorized the emergency use of the Sinovac CoronaVac COVID-19 Vaccine individuals 18 years of age and older.

Who should NOT get the Sinovac CoronaVac COVID-19 Vaccine: 
You should not get the Sinovac CoronaVac COVID-19 Vaccine if you:
 • had a severe allergic reaction after a previous dose of this vaccine
 • had a severe allergic reaction to any ingredient of this vaccine

Company: Oxford
Type of Vaccine: Chimpanzee adenovirus
Number of Shots: 2 shots, 28 days apart into muscle 
Effectiveness: 90%
Does NOT contain: Eggs, preservatives, latex

 What is the AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine?
The AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine is an unapproved vaccine that may preventCOVID-19. There is no FDA-approved vaccine to prevent COVID-19.The FDA has authorized the emergency use of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine to prevent COVID-19 in individuals 12 years of age and older under an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).

Who should get the AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine? 
FDA has authorized the emergency use of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine individuals 18 years of age and older.

Who should NOT get the AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine 
You should not get the AstraZeneca COVID-19 Vaccine if you:
 • had a severe allergic reaction after a previous dose of this vaccine
 • had a severe allergic reaction to any ingredient of this vaccine

1. 		 The Covid-19 vaccine may lead to side effects as stated in the Covid-19 Vaccine Information for Recipients. 

2. 		 The signatory is responsible for any possible risks because the benefits far outweigh the side effects. 

3. 		 The vaccine does not guarantee the signatory will not be infected with Covid-19 in the future. 

4. 		 The signatory consents to receiving the vaccine voluntarily to complete the vaccination as scheduled. 

5. 		 Currently employed on a paid basis in an eligible occupation in Phase 1A. 

6. 		 Currently employed on a paid or unpaid (volunteer) basis in an eligible occupation in Phase 1B. 

7. 		 A resident of a residential aged care facility or living in a disability facility. 

8. 		 A household contact of a quarantine or border worker eligible under Phase 1A. 

9. 		 Aged 50 years or older. 

10. 		 Undergone or undergoing one or more of the specified treatments or procedures for Phase 1B. 

11. 		 Diagnosed by a medical practitioner with one or more of the specified medical conditions for Phase 1B. 

12. 		 Diagnosed with a disability or age-related condition and am attending center-based services. 

13. 		 An essential career of a person with a disability or elderly person eligible under Phase 1A or Phase 1B.

string.name: b_please_read_the_declaration_below_carefully_b
string.b: Please read the declaration below carefully: \n

string.name: SubheadingDeclare
string.b: People who are eligible under Phase 1A and Phase 1B of the rollout:

resources.string:
1. 		 People currently employed as frontline healthcare workers. 

2. 		 People currently employed as quarantine and border workers. 

3. 		 People currently residing or employed in residential aged care and disability care facilities.

1. 		 People currently employed on a paid or unpaid (volunteer) basis. 

 2. 		 A household contact of a quarantine or border worker eligible under Phase 1A. 'Household contact' means that you currently live at the same primary address. 

 3. 		 Carer (paid or unpaid) of a person with a disability or an elderly person eligible in Phase 1A or 1B. This includes if a family member is providing essential care to a person with a disability or an elderly person eligible in Phase 1A or 1B, but does not include family members who are not carers. This includes carers of children with underlying medical conditions who would be eligible in Phase 1b but cannot be vaccinated due to age restrictions on approved COVID-19 vaccinations. For clarity, the elderly person or person with a disability does not need to be residing in an aged care facility or residential disability accommodation. 

 4. 		 People who have been diagnosed with a disability or with age-related conditions (e.g. early onset dementia) attending centre-based services (e.g. day programs, respite care, supported employment). 

 5. 		 People who have either undergone or are undergoing one or more of the following treatments or procedures. 

 6. 		 People who have been diagnosed by a medical practitioner with one or more of the following edical conditions (this eligibility criteria applies to people aged 69 years and under)
Please ensure that all information provided is complete and accurate for a smooth and fuss-free registration.
VACCINE NOW\nREGISTER FOR YOU VACCINATION NOW
I confirm that I have read, consent and agree to the agreement of COVID-19 vaccination.\nI understand the risk and side effects of vaccines
Are you interested to take the COVID-19 vaccine?
Have you registered with the Department of Social Welfare Malaysia as a Disabled Person (OKU)?
What is/are your reason(s) of not agreeing to receive COVID-19 vaccine (Your may select more than one reasons):
Unsure that the vaccine can protect me from the infection of COVID-19 pandemic
Vaccine is not required for me as COVID-19 is not dangerous
I have some health problems (e.g. allergy, high blood pressure, diabetes, heart diseases, cancer, etc.)
Are you with underlying medical conditions?

COVID-19 is a disease caused by a virus called SARS-CoV-2. Most people with COVID-19 have mild symptoms, but some people can become severely ill. Although most people with COVID-19 get better within weeks of illness, some people experience post-COVID conditions. Post-COVID conditions are a wide range of new, returning, or ongoing health problems people can experience more than four weeks after first being infected with the virus that causes COVID-19. Older people and those who have certain underlying medical conditions are more likely to get severely ill from COVID-19. Vaccines against COVID-19 are safe and effective.

string.name: faqQ2
string.b: Why is the disease being called Coronovirus disease 2019, COVID-19

resources.string: On February 11, 2020 the World Health Organization announced an official name for the disease that is causing the 2019 novel coronavirus pandemic, first identified in Wuhan China. The new name of this disease is coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated as COVID-19. In COVID-19, “CO” stands for corona, “VI” for virus, and ”D” for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as “2019 novel coronavirus” or “2019-nCoV.”

string.name: faqQ4
string.b: How to protect myself from COVID-19?

string.name: faqQ5
string.b: How many and where are KKM Hospital?

resources.string:
1. 		Get a COVID-19 vaccine as soon as you can. 

 2. 		Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others. 

 3. 		Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you. 

 4. 		Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces. 

 5. 		Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.
No worries! Your may update your personal information \nby email to Vaccine Now customer service center \nvia vaccinenow@gmail.com
